text: Developed and narrated by Sam Lee
The cars we drive to work, and the planes we go on for vacations are safer than ever.
And we can thank safety regulations for that.
What we tend to overlook is that the regulations are usually written in blood.
For example, the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster led NASA to be more mindful of shuttle temperatures.
But, NASA, learned those lessons at the cost of seven human lives.
There is unfortunately, no shortage of accidents in aviation history books.
I find one aircraft accident in Japan fascinating.
It is a story of how a small mistake led to a tragic outcome.
It is Monday, August the twelfth in 1985.
Japan Airlines Flight 123 was a routine passenger flight at Tokyo's Haneda Airport.
It was bound for Osaka International Airport.
Takeoff was ordinary, and there were no faults to be found.
Thirteen minutes into the air, the captain of the flight declared an emergency back to Tokyo.
The captain then requested to return to Haneda and was immediately approved.
The plane struggled to head back.
After 44 long minutes, the Boeing 747 disappeared from radar and crashed 62 miles away from Haneda, in Ueno, Gunma Prefecture.
This accident killed 520 out of the 524 onboard.
We will see how the crash happened and the heroic attempts of the pilots.
